ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: I audited the class. Kyzar is a sharp guy, but the class could have been a little more interactive, with less lecturing from him and more opinions from students.
Good class but not sure I actually learned anything. Class discussions needed to be better managed to keep the super-eager kids from taking over the discussions.
I love this professor. I learned a lot from his classes!
I audited this course
Question 4: The amount of reading was really heavy but there were no assignments which was nice. I also liked that we had options for the final assignment.
YLS courses arereally great. Professor Kysar's course was excellent. His teaching style is wonderful and the course material was excellent.

This course is a refresher to a lot of the climate policy work you can find in other FES classes. The difference is that Kysar is very good at inspiring class discussion and you learn some introductory thoughts on the law perspective on traditional climate issues.
The readings for the course were out of date.

There was a lot of hot air from fellow students which the professor kindly wanted to acknowledge but wasn't very useful to learning. I also feel like there is a lot of reading that must be done in order to really get a lot out of the class. Lastly, the professor is so passionate and interested in the topic - it really might do better as a seminar!

I very much enjoyed the visiting speakers and would like to see them again in future editions of the course. However, it would be nice if speakers were some time outside of class so that they did not take away from the overall material.
It was made quite interesting by initiating interactions.

This course was designed more like a seminar course that relies on small group discussion. In a large class setting it did not seem to work as well. I really would have liked a bit more structure and introduction to the law material. I found that I did not learn enough about the legal tools as I would have liked.
Professor Kysar is a great lecturer - he's extremely knowledgeable about many aspects of climate change, and also a great public speaker.
Professor is clearly very interested and passionate about the material, and invested in helping students become leaders in this area.
Interesting readings, topics, class discussions.
The excellent professor.
The instructor's all-encompassing approach to the topic. Good structure and relevant readings.

Professor Kysar is fabulous, great at explaining clearly and keeping the class interesting for people with a wide variety of knowledge levels. I would give this class an A+. Great, engaging lecture style, and the course is very up to date and covered the most recent climate change law developments. Guest lecturers were also great.
The knowledgeable and articulate students who brought a range of backgrounds and perspectives to the course.
The professor is a great lecturer and very engaging. It was great listening in on classroom discussions.
The breadth of the material and the amount of material that we covered. Kysar's lectures were very informative and entertaining. I also really appreciate how passionate he is about the material.
Learning about climate law from Professor Kysar. His lectures and readings covered the topic from so many different angles. Excellent work Professor Kysar!

The readings were very timely and interesting regarding both domestic and international climate policies. Professor Kysar is very engaging with students and brings a certain optimism to the field of climate law (even if he thinks he is being pessimistic most of the time).
Great professor
Professor Kysar is amazing and very engagingcover good range of topicsa bit repetitive if you've taking EL&P or other policy classes
Kysar is a sensational speaker and teacher. His lectures and lecture slides were excellent.
Professor Kysar is an excellent and engaging lecturer! He is clearly very passionate about the topic, and he makes it personal, which I very much appreciated. It really makes the class rewarding.
Professor Kyzar's lectures from PowerPoint were enjoyable, concise, and very informative.
The interactions and also the in depth analysis or explanations of issues with cases
great overview of what is going on with the discussion of climate change, global to local scales.
I really enjoy Professor Kysar's lively and humorous lecturing style. He is clearly was well informed on this topic, encourages discussion, and wants students to learn.
Professor Kysar is wonderful! The lectures were fascinating. The material is very interesting and relevant.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: Difficult to balance between people who know a lot about climate and law, and people who have never studied it.
Keeping the class focused.
It would be nice if we had smaller discussion sections so that everyone could feel comfortable talking.
Better targeted readings - perhaps indications of required and recommended readings to make sure students are actually completing the important ones.
Perhaps more encouragement of multiple-person dialogue, rather than soliciting just individuals' comments.
I can't think of anything to improve.
It's so broad! I don't know how it can be any different thought. As a non-law student the volume of reading surprised me.
The lectures could be a little clearer. As a non-law student I feel that the cases were rushed through and I would have appreciated a little more explanation.
Class size was way too big for discussion.

Some restructuring would be nice to get into more depth on a few topics rather than giving a broad brush to everything. For instance, the day focusing on litigation strategies was helpful but could have gone into more depth. Perhaps have students analyze a climate related case in more depth as a class assignment.
a little less reading...?
The reading list is out of date, and a little boring.
Again, too much participation from students, especially particular students. The professor could try to cut this off once in a while.

The course was originally designed to be a seminar, and it would have been nice to have been nice if there were more opportunities to comment either in section or elsewhere. Class discussions were unfortunately dominated by several talkative students.
Practicals or some exercises like real/ moot court trials.
More background materials for students with non-law background. It was very difficult to jump into the readings without them.

If the class is this large, have more structure to it. I also found that completing the final in just 3 hours seems very challenging. We were given 24 hours, so it was not a problem to finish it but was told that the intention is that this is a 3 hour exam.
The format of the class was ideal for a seminar, so it should be slightly adjusted if it ends up as a lecture again.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: No TA. Professor was available in office hours.
Great!
Professor Kysar is amazing, very responsive and a wonderful and caring teacher.
The best!
N/A
My impression that Kysar was available but I never went to see him. I did email him and he was very responsive.
Professor was very available.
Instructor was great and made himself available. Very accessible. fun to learn from
Yes. The professor is always open and available to chat with students.
Professor Kyzar was very helpful and very willing to meet.
Instructors cooperation and support was excellent.
Doug Kysar is fantastic! He always makes time for students and provides great advice and feedback.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: Focused on climate policy, so this course was very relevant for me.
A good synthesis and way to draw together knowledge I have gained from various disciplinary approaches and aspects of this problem.
This course fits perfectly into my area of concentration; it reinforces things I had learned previously while exposing me to a whole new angle--that of domestic US litigation tactics.
A great joint perspective with the law school to investigate legal mechanisms of an essential environmental issue.

I am working on climate issues and this course was important to put my work in a legal perspective. I would also like to work in the non-profit organization on climate issues and knowing the current status of climate law will help me understand the best way forward on addressing mitigation and adaptation.
I study climate diplomacy, so this course was right up my alley. I was great to learn a vast amount of material in this course.

This was a great survey course on climate policy in the U.S. and internationally. It also brings legal hooks into the mix for ways to force policy change. I think it is a great survey course for anyone interested in the current state of climate policy.
This is one of the reasons I came to Yale - the interdisciplinary understanding of climate change policy.

As an undergraduate getting my BS/MS in chemistry, this course was very helpful in increasing my knowledge of environmental law in general and the climate change problem in particular. As someone interested in working in environmental advocacy in the future, this course was especially important.
This the most wanted knowledge field in my area of work
Working on a project about climate change, so it was helpful to know overall structure of the discussion.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I'm focused on climate policy, and wanted a clearer sense of current law and possible new areas of law regarding climate change.
For the subject and for the professor.
Because it fits my concentration and offered a chance to see the Law School.
To get a legal perspective on climate change.
interested in learning more about climate change law. I had not taking a class in this area at FES and thought that it would be a good introduction.
Because the subject matter interested me and because I heard glowing reviews of professor Kysar.
I wanted to know more about climate change law.
As a survey climate course.
See above
I took this course to learn about what US and International Environmental law and their interface with the issue of Climate Change.
To have in-depth knowledge of the climate laws

Wanted a better understanding of climate change law and to bolster my understanding law/litigation in the US. Professor Kysar's introductory class was extremely interesting and thought provoking and so was the entire course
because I am working on climate change projects, and wanted to have a well-rounded understanding of the issue.
I am interested in the material and enjoy Professor Kysar's lecturing style.
Next year, I will begin a joint JD/MEM program, so I wanted to make sure I would like the material.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Overall thought it was very engaging and I've learned a lot.
yes
Yes. It was an amazing experience.
Yes.
YES!
Totally
Yes
yes
kind of. I really enjoyed the course and I feel like I learned a lot but I am not sure that the information I learned is in a "form" that I can easily draw upon.
This course exceeded my expectations. I was exposed to a wide array of ideas concepts, and facts about climate change.
Yes.
Yes
Yes, except I expected to be able to participate more in in-class discussions.
Yes, I enjoyed it.
Yes
yes

While I enjoyed the course, it did not quite meet my expectations in arming me with legal tools for the future. It was much more of a conceptual debate but even the concepts were just loosely covered. Without a legal background I think my fellow FESers did not get as much out of the content.
Absolutely!

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Kind of. Needed more background learning to make sense of the lectures.
yes
Yes.
Yes.
YES!
Definitively
Yes
yes
I think I learned how little legal options there are for addressing climate change- I was hoping to have more on the ground tools but what I learned is that those don't really exist.
To got more than I expected. This was a wonderful course that really allowed me to dive into the material. Well done!
Yes.
Yes
Yes, and more.
Yes
Yes
yes
Yes!

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: My teammate on the final project/paper was great, we learned a lot together.
No group exercise was done

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Try to do the readings and participate in class discussion.
Do not be intimidated by the reading; it's all relevant.
Be prepared for the reading.
Do as many of the readings as possible. If a lot of reading is assigned, try to skim everything. You will get a lot more out of class discussions this way.
If you want to learn about a broad swath of material relating to climate and environmental law. Take this course. This is must-take course for FES students.

Do all of the readings with each week. I would read 2 of the 4 or 5 readings consistently. Most of us did all of the readings at the end of the semester because they tended to be lengthy every week but Professor Kysar really hit on all of the themes of all of the readings each class.
Definitely take it if you are interested in climate policy in general - but not if you have already taken other related courses / read the newspaper about COPs etc.
Don't miss your chance to hear Kysar lecture.
do the reading!
This was a great course if you are willing to take the time to do the readings. It is far beyond just an overview of climate change as a problem.
they should do reading beyond the specified ones also and participate in class discussions.
Great class. Take any class offered by Prof Kysar !
Do the readings and try to engage with the material presented in lectures. Get to know Doug Kysar.
